articles.headline: Automakers Race Time as Their Cash Runs Low
articles.snippet: As G.M. and Ford burn through their reserves and slash more costs to stay afloat, the future looks tenuous.
articles.abstract: As G.M. and Ford burn through their reserves and slash more costs to stay afloat, the future looks tenuous.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The downturn in the American auto industry is rapidly becoming a full-blown fight for survival among Detroit’s big automakers.

articles.headline: Jobless Rate Climbs to 5.7% as 51,000 Jobs Are Lost in July
articles.snippet: Payrolls contracted for the seventh consecutive month, but the loss was less than the 75,000 jobs that economists had expected.
articles.abstract: Payrolls contracted for the seventh consecutive month, but the loss was less than the 75,000 jobs that economists had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate spiked again in July, to 5.7 percent, its highest level in more than four years and a strong signal that come Election Day millions of Americans will still be hunting for work.

articles.headline: Whole Foods Looks for a Fresh Image in Lean Times
articles.snippet: Whole Foods Market is on a mission to revise its gold-plated image, working to convince consumers that it can be an economical place to shop.
articles.abstract: Whole Foods Market is on a mission to revise its gold-plated image, working to convince consumers that it can be an economical place to shop.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Shawn Hebb may have one of America’s toughest jobs: convincing people that Whole Foods Market can be an economical place to shop.

articles.headline: With Genie Out of Bottle, Obama Is Careful on Race
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s formidable network was uncharacteristically quiet on the issue of how race got injected into the contest.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s formidable network was uncharacteristically quiet on the issue of how race got injected into the contest.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Vote Sets Precedent on Unfettered Web Usage
articles.snippet: The F.C.C. upheld a complaint against Comcast, which it said had illegally inhibited users of its high-speed Internet service from using popular file-sharing software.
articles.abstract: The F.C.C. upheld a complaint against Comcast, which it said had illegally inhibited users of its high-speed Internet service from using popular file-sharing software.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission formally voted Friday to uphold the complaint against Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company, saying that it had illegally inhibited users of its high-speed Internet service from using popular file-sharing software. The decision, which imposes no fine, requires Comcast to end such blocking this year.

articles.headline: The S.E.C. Is Investigating Fee Practices at Value Line
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. is investigating whether the company, which publishes several well-known investment newsletters, has overcharged the mutual funds it advises.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. is investigating whether the company, which publishes several well-known investment newsletters, has overcharged the mutual funds it advises.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top managers at Value Line, the company known for its scrutiny of management at other companies, have themselves attracted some scrutiny from federal regulators.

articles.headline: Despite Flaws, Rights in China Have Expanded
articles.snippet: Political change in China, however gradual and inconsistent, has made it a significantly more open place for many people than it was a generation ago.
articles.abstract: Political change in China, however gradual and inconsistent, has made it a significantly more open place for many people than it was a generation ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  For the past two decades, China’s people became richer but not much freer, and the Communist Party has staked its future on their willingness to live with that tradeoff.

articles.headline: Ditch the Gas Guzzler? Well, Maybe Not Yet
articles.snippet: There are some questions to consider if you are tempted to get rid of your S.U.V., and some tips for figuring out whether it may be more financially sensible to hang onto it for a little longer.
articles.abstract: There are some questions to consider if you are tempted to get rid of your S.U.V., and some tips for figuring out whether it may be more financially sensible to hang onto it for a little longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Your neighbors may turn up their noses, but keeping your gas-guzzling sport utility vehicle, or buying one coming off a lease, may be a smart move.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Don’t Want to Talk About It? Order a Missed Call
articles.snippet: A system called Slydial lets callers dial a cellphone and go right to voice mail, avoiding an unwanted conversation.
articles.abstract: A system called Slydial lets callers dial a cellphone and go right to voice mail, avoiding an unwanted conversation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Alexis Gorman, 26, wanted to tell a man she had been dating that the courtship was over, she felt sending a Dear John text message was too impersonal. But she worried that if she called the man, she would face an awkward conversation or a confrontation.

articles.headline: Shipping Costs Start to Crimp Globalization
articles.snippet: Cheap oil, the lubricant of inexpensive transportation links, may not return soon, upsetting the logic of diffuse global supply chains.
articles.abstract: Cheap oil, the lubricant of inexpensive transportation links, may not return soon, upsetting the logic of diffuse global supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tesla Motors, a pioneer in electric-powered cars, set out to make a luxury roadster for the American market, it had the global supply chain in mind. Tesla planned to manufacture 1,000-pound battery packs in Thailand, ship them to Britain for installation, then bring the mostly assembled cars back to the United States.

articles.headline: Immigrants Facing Deportation by U.S. Hospitals
articles.snippet: Many hospitals are taking it upon themselves to repatriate seriously injured or ill immigrants because nursing homes won’t accept them without insurance.
articles.abstract: Many hospitals are taking it upon themselves to repatriate seriously injured or ill immigrants because nursing homes won’t accept them without insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOLOMCÚ, Guatemala  High in the hills of Guatemala, shut inside the one-room house where he spends day and night on a twin bed beneath a seriously outdated calendar, Luis Alberto Jiménez has no idea of the legal battle that swirls around him in the lowlands of Florida.

articles.headline: Anthrax Case Renews Questions on Bioterror
articles.snippet: Some people say a boom in biodefense research has actually increased access to dangerous germs.
articles.abstract: Some people say a boom in biodefense research has actually increased access to dangerous germs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Until the anthrax attacks of 2001, Bruce E. Ivins was one of just a few dozen American bioterrorism researchers working with the most lethal biological pathogens, almost all at high-security military laboratories.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Scott Shane

articles.headline: An S.B.A. Lender, Uncensored
articles.snippet: A report reveals the extent of the oversight of the Small Business Administration in taking action against an S.B.A. lender, whose shortcomings had been noted since 2001.
articles.abstract: A report reveals the extent of the oversight of the Small Business Administration in taking action against an S.B.A. lender, whose shortcomings had been noted since 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH the American taxpayer assuming responsibility for all manner of bad loans made by reckless lenders, it is puzzling that a scathing 2007 audit of the Small Business Administration’s oversight of one of its top private lenders remains hidden from view.

articles.headline: Delicate Obama Path on Class and Race Preferences
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s background may make him a bridge between racial sensibilities, but the issue is treacherous.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s background may make him a bridge between racial sensibilities, but the issue is treacherous.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1990, as his fellow students rallied to protest the dearth of black professors at Harvard Law School, Barack Obama wrote a vigorous defense of affirmative action. The campus was in an uproar over questions of race, and Mr. Obama, then the first black president of The Harvard Law Review, decided to take a stand.

articles.headline: Yahoo Is Still Searching for, Well, Yahoo
articles.snippet: With the stock down, many shareholders are questioning whether Jerry Yang is the right man to lead Yahoo.
articles.abstract: With the stock down, many shareholders are questioning whether Jerry Yang is the right man to lead Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.

articles.headline: The Chips Are Down in Vegas, but Steve Wynn Is Betting Big
articles.snippet: Steve Wynn is expanding his casino empire at a precarious time: some fear that the big spenders will start to cut back.
articles.abstract: Steve Wynn is expanding his casino empire at a precarious time: some fear that the big spenders will start to cut back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Las Vegas

articles.headline: Ragtag Taliban Show Tenacity in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The mounting toll inflicted by insurgents has refocused the attention of America’s military commanders.
articles.abstract: The mounting toll inflicted by insurgents has refocused the attention of America’s military commanders.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six years after being driven from power, the Taliban are demonstrating a resilience and a ferocity that are raising alarm here, in Washington and in other NATO capitals, and engendering a fresh round of soul-searching over how a relatively ragtag insurgency has managed to keep the world’s most powerful armies at bay.

articles.headline: Out of FEMA Park, Clinging to a Fraying Lifeline
articles.snippet: Many Katrina evacuees are struggling after the closing of a trailer park that was home to hundreds.
articles.abstract: Many Katrina evacuees are struggling after the closing of a trailer park that was home to hundreds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La.  Two months ago, as he left the trailer park he called home after Hurricane Katrina, Alton Love, 41, just knew he was on the brink of getting a working car, an apartment and a good job to support the 9-year-old daughter he is raising on his own.

articles.headline: Screen Actors Guild Is Divided Against Itself
articles.snippet: Infuriated by hard-line tactics used by SAG leaders in contract talks with studios, a less militant collection of actors has started a campaign to take over the guild.
articles.abstract: Infuriated by hard-line tactics used by SAG leaders in contract talks with studios, a less militant collection of actors has started a campaign to take over the guild.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The quest by the Screen Actors Guild for a sharply improved labor contract has a new plot line: mutiny.

articles.headline: Rematch in Senate Race Finds a New Climate
articles.snippet: New Hampshire, which has shifted hard toward the Democrats in recent years, is emblematic of the national political terrain.
articles.abstract: New Hampshire, which has shifted hard toward the Democrats in recent years, is emblematic of the national political terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H.  The maverick voters of New Hampshire love to keep politicians guessing.

articles.headline: Grim News for a Paper in Jersey
articles.snippet: In a state with a record of corruption that needs watching, its major newspaper is looking for buyouts from a quarter of the newsroom.
articles.abstract: In a state with a record of corruption that needs watching, its major newspaper is looking for buyouts from a quarter of the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Friday morning was a glorious one in suburban New Jersey. At 6 a.m., the heat of the morning leaked in through the window, accompanied by the huge racket of cicadas thrumming in unison. It was the kind of morning where someone might be tempted to just lie there pretending to sleep, but then another sound came: the thwack of fresh, hot newspaper hitting the sidewalk.

articles.headline: Housing Lenders Fear Bigger Wave of Loan Defaults
articles.snippet: Homeowners with good credit are falling behind on their payments in growing numbers, just as the problems with subprime mortgages are leveling off.
articles.abstract: Homeowners with good credit are falling behind on their payments in growing numbers, just as the problems with subprime mortgages are leveling off.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first wave of Americans to default on their home mortgages appears to be cresting, but a second, far larger one is quickly building.

articles.headline: Media Outlets Are Seeking a Campaign Bounce of Their Own
articles.snippet: Voter interest in the presidential race may be soaring, but many media companies are struggling to translate coverage into repeat readers and viewers -- or revenue.
articles.abstract: Voter interest in the presidential race may be soaring, but many media companies are struggling to translate coverage into repeat readers and viewers -- or revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential campaign has drawn more voter interest than any other race in generations. For mainstream news media, however, capitalizing on that interest has been hit or miss, though not for lack of trying.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: An Acid-Tongued Maverick Keeps Bankers on the Edge of Their Seats
articles.snippet: Richard X. Bove is one of the few analysts to predict the housing market blow-up. He is also one of the few whose advice would have made money for investors over the past year.
articles.abstract: Richard X. Bove is one of the few analysts to predict the housing market blow-up. He is also one of the few whose advice would have made money for investors over the past year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lutz, Fla., is on no one’s list of world financial capitals. But from his home there on Tiffany Lane, 1,100 miles from Wall Street, Richard X. Bove can rattle the mighty of American banking.

articles.headline: Applications Spur Carriers to Relax Grip on Cellphones
articles.snippet: The proliferation of new applications and the realization that they make cellphones more popular has convinced carriers that they need to give consumers more freedom.
articles.abstract: The proliferation of new applications and the realization that they make cellphones more popular has convinced carriers that they need to give consumers more freedom.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the first 10 days after Apple opened its App Store for the iPhone, consumers downloaded more than 25 million applications, ranging from games like Super Monkey Ball to tools like New York City subway maps. It was nothing short of revolutionary, not only because the number was so high but also because iPhone users could do it at all.
